xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Local Policies Group
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: This section includes legacy audit policy settings, user rights assignment policy settings, and security options policy settings.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Audit Policy Settings
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Windows XP includes powerful system auditing capabilities. The purpose of auditing is to record certain types of actions to a log, so that system administrators can review the logs and detect unauthorized activity. Audit logs may also be helpful when investigating a security incident that has occurred. As shown in Table 6-1, system auditing is available for logon events, account management, directory service access, object access, policy change, privilege use, process tracking, and system events. Each audit policy category can be configured to record successful events, failed events, both successful and failed events, or neither. Section 7.3 describes how file auditing can be configured, as well as how the Event Viewer can be used to review log entries.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit Account Logon Events
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Audits when a user logs on or off a remote computer from this workstation.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit Account Management
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Audits when a user account or group is created, changed, or deleted; a user account is renamed, disabled, or enabled; a password is set or changed.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit Directory Service Access
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Audit Directory Service Access

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit Logon Events
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Audits users logging on, logging off, or making a network connection to the local computer.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit Object Access
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Audits a user accessing an object (for example, a file, folder, registry key, or printer) that has its own SACL specified.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit Policy Change
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Audits every change to user rights assignment policies, audit policies, and trust policies.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit Privilege Use
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Audits each instance of a user exercising a user right.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit System Events
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Audits when a user restarts or shuts down the computer or when an event occurs that affects either the system security or the security log.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Audit Account Logon Events
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Audits when a user logs on or off a remote computer from this workstation.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Audit Policy

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Audit Account Management
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Audits when a user account or group is created, changed, or deleted; a user account is renamed, disabled, or enabled; a password is set or changed.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Audit Policy

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Audit Directory Service Access
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Audits the event of a user accessing an active directory object that has its own System Access Control List (SACL) specified. This setting is not applicable to Windows XP systems.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Audit Policy

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Audit Logon Events
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Audits users logging on, logging off, or making a network connection to the local computer.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Audit Policy

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Audit Object Access
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Audits a user accessing an object (for example, a file, folder, registry key, or printer) that has its own SACL specified. Auditing of success or failure of system wide object access will create numerous log entries. Certain object access failures may be normal as a result of applications requesting all access types to objects, even though the application does not require all access types to function properly. Use object access auditing with caution.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Audit Policy

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Audit Policy Change
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Audits every change to user rights assignment policies, audit policies, and trust policies.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Audit Policy

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Audit Privilege Use
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Audits each instance of a user exercising a user right. This is likely to generate a very large number of events.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Audit Policy

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Audit System Events
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Audits when a user restarts or shuts down the computer or when an event occurs that affects either the system security or the security log.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Audit Policy

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Security Options Settings
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description:
Besides the Local Security Policy settings mentioned earlier in this section, additional settings called Security Options can be modified to achieve greater security than the default settings provide. The NIST templates specify values for dozens of such settings. Examples of the types of settings available are as follows:
Limiting the use of blank passwords
Renaming the default Administrator and Guest accounts
Restricting remote access to floppy and CD-ROM drives
Encrypting secure channel data in a domain
Securing the interactive logon screen (e.g., not showing the previous user's account name, displaying a warning banner, prompting users to change passwords before they expire)
Restricting which types of network access may be performed
Specifying which types of authentication may be used (e.g., NTLM v2).The Security Options settings can also be accessed and adjusted manually by performing the following steps:
From the Start menu, choose Control Panel.
Select Administrative Tools, and then choose Local Security Policy.
Expand Local Policies and select Security Options.
The right pane lists the security option and indicates the current setting for each. Make any necessary changes by double-clicking on the appropriate security option, modifying the setting, and clicking OK to save the change.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Accounts: Administrator account status
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Administrator account status is enabled to allow the administrator to perform configuration control of the system.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Status of Guest Account
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value defines the desired status of the built-in Guest account. 1 = enabled

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Status of Blank Password
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value defines the desired status of limiting the use of blank passwords. 1 = enabled

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit the use of Backup and Restore privilege
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value defines the whether use of the Backup and Restore privilege will be audited. 01 = enabled

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit: Audit the access of global system objects
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Controls the ability to audit access of global systems objects. When this setting is enabled, system objects such as mutexes, events, semaphores, and DOS devices, are created with a default system access control list (SACL).

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit: Shut down system immediately if unable to log security audits
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: If events cannot be written to the security log, the system is halted immediately. If the system halts as a result of a full log, an administrator must log onto the system and clear the log.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Devices: Allow only administrators to format and eject removable media
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Verifies that only the correct users are allowed to format and eject removable media 0 - Only Administrator, 1 - Only Administrators and power users, 2 - Only Administrators and Interactive user

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Prevent Users From Installing Printer Drivers
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Defines who is allowed to add and to delete printer drivers on the local system. 0 = disabled

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Restrict Access to CDROM Drive
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value determines if access to the CDROM drive is restricted to locally logged-on users. 1 = restricted

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Restrict Access to Floppy Drive
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value determines if access to the floppy drive is restricted to locally logged-on users. 1 = restricted

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Devices: Unsigned driver installation behavior
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: When an attempt is made to install a device driver (by means of the Windows XP device installer) that has not been certified by the Windows Hardware Quality Lab (WHQL), a warning should be issued, but the installation allowed to continue.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Maximum Machine Account Password Age
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This setting controls the maximum password age that a machine account may have.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Require Strong (Windows 2000 or Later) Session Key
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This setting controls the required strength of a session key.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Number of Previous Logons to Cache (in Case Domain Controller Is Not Available)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Defines the number of last logon credentials cached for users who log on interactively to a system.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Prompt User to Change Password Before Expiration
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This setting configures the system to display a warning to users telling them how many days are left before their password expires.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Require Domain Controller Authentication to Unlock Workstation
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This setting controls the behavior of the system when you attempt to unlock the workstation. If this setting is enabled, the system will pass the credentials to the domain controller (if in a domain) for authentication before allowing the system to be unlocked.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Smart Card Removal Behavior
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value determines the desired behavior when a smart card is removed. 0 - No action 1 - Lock workstation 2 - Force logoff

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Client Digitally Sign Communications (Always)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the client policy is set to always sign packets.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Send unencrypted password to third-party SMB servers
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Status of allowing system to send unencrypted password to third-party SMB servers.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Amount of Idle Time Required Before Suspending Session
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Administrators should use this setting to control when a computer disconnects an inactive SMB session. If client activity resumes, the session is automatically reestablished.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Client Forced to Disconnect
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Specifies whether the server should force a client to disconnect, even if the client has open files, once the client's logon time has expired.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Minimum session security for NTLM SSP based (including secure RPC) clients
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value specifies the minimum required security setting of client-side network connections for applications using the NTLM security support provider (SSP).

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Minimum session security for NTLM SSP based (including secure RPC) servers
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value specifies the minimum required security setting of server-side network connections for applications using the NTLM security support provider (SSP).

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Enable Automatic Logon Disabled
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Enable Automatic Logon Disabled

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: IP source routing protection level
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: IP source routing protection level

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Allow automatic detection of dead network gateways
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Allow automatic detection of dead network gateways

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Allow ICMP redirects to override OSPF generated routes
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Allow ICMP redirects to override OSPF generated routes

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: EnablePMTUDiscovery
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: EnablePMTUDiscovery

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: How Often Keep-Alive Packets Are Sent in Milliseconds
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the system is configured to control how often TCP attempts to verify that an idle connection is still intact by sending a keep-alive packet.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (NoDefaultExempt) Enable NoDefaultExempt for IPSec Filtering (recommended)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: MSS: (NoDefaultExempt) Enable NoDefaultExempt for IPSec Filtering

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Allow the computer to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Allow the computer to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Allow the computer to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Allow the computer to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: RouterDiscovery
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: RouterDiscovery value

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: ScreenSaverGracePeriod
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: ScreenSaverGracePeriod value

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: SynAttackProtectionLevel
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: SynAttackProtectionLevel value

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: TcpMaxConnectResponseRetransmissions
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: TcpMaxConnectResponseRetransmissions value

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: How Many Times Unacknowledged Data Is Retransmitted
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the system is configured to control the maximum number of times that TCP retransmits unacknowledged data segments before aborting the attempt.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Percentage Threshold for the Security Event Log at Which the System Will Generate a Warning
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the system is configured to generate a warning when the Security Event Log has reached a defined threshold.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network access: Allow anonymous SID-Name translation
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Determines if an anonymous user can request security identifier (SID) attributes for another user or use a SID to get the corresponding username.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Domain member: Digitally encrypt or sign secure channel data (always)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Domain member: Digitally encrypt or sign secure channel data (always). Requests sent on the secure channel are authenticated, and sensitive information (such as passwords) is encrypted or signed. If this policy is enabled, outgoing secure channel traffic should be encrypted.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (always)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the server policy is set to always sign packets.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Shutdown: Allow system to be shut down without having to log on
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Displaying the shutdown button may allow individuals to shut down a system anonymously. Only authenticated users should be allowed to shut down the system. Preventing display of this button in the logon dialog box, ensures that individuals who shut down the system are authorized and tracked in the systems Security event log.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Shutdown: Clear virtual memory pagefile
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Virtual memory support of Windows XP uses a system page file to swap blocks of memory not actively being used to disk. While Windows XP is running, this file is opened exclusively by the operating system, thus ensuring it is reasonably protected. However, the system page file should be wiped clean of all user data when the system shuts down. This ensures that sensitive information that may be in the page file is not available for retrieval by an anonymous user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Accounts: Administrator account status
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The Administrator account status is enabled to allow the administrator to perform configuration control of the system.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Accounts: Guest account status
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: A system faces an increased vulnerability threat if the built-in guest account is not disabled. This account is a known account that exists on all Windows systems and cannot be deleted. This account is initialized during the installation of the operating system with no password assigned. This account is a member of the Everyone user group and has all the rights and permissions associated with that group, which could subsequently provide access to system resources to anonymous users. Ensure the built-in guest account is disabled.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Accounts: Limit local account use of blank passwords to console logon only
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: In Windows XP Professional, accounts with null or blank passwords can only be used to log on at the physical system's logon screen. This means that accounts with blank or null passwords cannot be used over networks or with the secondary logon service (RunAs). This feature prevents attackers and malware from gaining remote access through blank passwords. Section 6 contains information on other recommended password settings.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Accounts: Rename administrator account
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The Administrator account is created by default when installing Windows XP, but is disabled. Associating the Administrator SID with a different name may thwart a potential hacker who is targeting the built-in Administrator account.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Accounts: Rename guest account
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The Guest account is created by default when installing Windows XP, but is disabled. Associating the Guest SID with a different name may thwart a potential hacker who is targeting the built-in Guest account.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Audit: Audit the access of global system objects
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Controls the ability to audit access of global systems objects. When this setting is enabled, system objects such as mutexes, events, semaphores, and DOS devices, are created with a default system access control list (SACL).

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Audit: Audit the use of Backup and Restore privilege
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Controls the ability to audit the use of all user privileges, including Backup and Restore. If this policy is disabled, certain user rights will not be audited even if "Audit privilege use" audit policy is enabled.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Audit: Shut down system immediately if unable to log security audits
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: If events cannot be written to the security log, the system is halted immediately. If the system halts as a result of a full log, an administrator must log onto the system and clear the log.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Devices: Allowed to format and eject removable media
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Verifies that only the correct users are allowed to format and eject removable media

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Devices: Prevent users from installing printer drivers
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting determines who is allowed to install a printer driver as part of adding a network printer.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Devices: Restrict CD-ROM access to locally logged-on user only
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Removable media devices (CD-ROM) are readable by others on the network if they are not properly configured. A process can remain running in the background after a user logs off, thereby, permitting access to the media, while another user is logged on to the system.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Devices: Restrict floppy access to locally logged-on user only
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Removable media devices (floppy disks) are readable by others on the network if they are not properly configured. A process can remain running in the background after a user logs off, thereby, permitting access to the media, while another user is logged on to the system.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Devices: Unsigned driver installation behavior
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: When an attempt is made to install a device driver (by means of the Windows XP device installer) that has not been certified by the Windows Hardware Quality Lab (WHQL), a warning should be issued, but the installation allowed to continue.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Domain member: Digitally encrypt or sign secure channel data (always)
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Domain member: Digitally encrypt or sign secure channel data (always). Requests sent on the secure channel are authenticated, and sensitive information (such as passwords) is encrypted or signed. If this policy is enabled, outgoing secure channel traffic should be encrypted.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Domain member: Digitally encrypt secure channel data (when possible)
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Requests sent on the secure channel are authenticated, and sensitive information (such as passwords) is encrypted, but not all information is encrypted. If this policy is enabled, outgoing secure channel traffic should be encrypted.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Domain member: Digitally sign secure channel data (when possible)
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Requests sent on the secure channel are authenticated, and sensitive information (such as passwords) is encrypted, but the channel is not integrity checked. If this policy is enabled, all outgoing secure channel traffic should be signed.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Domain member: Disable machine account password changes
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Computer account passwords are changed automatically every seven days. Enabling this policy to disable automatic password changes can make the system more vulnerable to malicious access. Frequent password changes can be a significant safeguard for your system. If this policy is disabled, a new password for the computer account will be generated every week.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Domain member: Maximum machine account password age
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting controls the maximum password age that a machine account may have. This setting should be set to no more that 30 days, ensuring that the machine changes its password monthly.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Domain member: Require strong session key
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting controls the required strength of a session key. Session keys in Windows XP are stronger than those in NT and should be used whenever possible.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Interactive logon: Do not display last user name
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting determines whether the name of the last user to log on to the computer will be displayed in the Windows logon dialog box.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Interactive logon: Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Disabling the Ctrl+Alt+Del security attention sequence can compromise system security. Because only Windows responds to the Ctrl+Alt+Del security sequence, you can be assured that any passwords you enter following that sequence are sent only to Windows. If you eliminate the sequence requirement, malicious programs can request and receive your Windows password. Disabling this sequence also suppresses a custom logon banner.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Interactive logon: Message text for users attempting to log on
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Failure to display the logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Interactive logon: Message title for users attempting to log on
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The logon banner should be titled with a warning label containing the name of the owning organization.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Interactive logon: Number of previous logons cached (in case domain controller is not available)
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The default Windows XP configuration caches the last logon credentials for users who log on interactively to a system. This feature is provided for system availability reasons such as the users machine is disconnected from the network or domain controllers are not available. Even though the credential cache is well-protected, storing encrypted copies of users passwords on workstations do not always have the same physical protection required for domain controllers. If a workstation is attacked, the unauthorized individual may isolate the password to a domain user account using a password-cracking program, and gain access to the domain.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Interactive logon: Prompt user to change password before expiration.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting configures the system to display a warning to users telling them how many days are left before their password expires. By giving the user advanced warning, the user has time to construct a sufficiently strong password.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting controls the behavior of the system when you attempt to unlock the workstation. If this setting is enabled, the system will pass the credentials to the domain controller (if in a domain) for authentication before allowing the system to be unlocked.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Interactive logon: Smart card removal behavior
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: When the smart card for a logged-on user is removed from the smart card reader, the workstation should be locked.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Microsoft network client: Digitally sign communications (always)
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the client policy is set to always sign packets.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Microsoft network client: Digitally sign communications (if server agrees)
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the client policy is set to sign packets if the server agrees.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Microsoft network client: Send unencrypted password to third-party SMB servers
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Some non-Microsoft SMB servers only support unencrypted (plain text) password authentication. Sending plain text passwords across the network, when authenticating to an SMB server, reduces the overall security of the environment. Check with the Vendor of the SMB server to see if there is a way to support encrypted password authentication.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Microsoft network server: Amount of idle time required before suspending session
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Administrators should use this setting to control when a computer disconnects an inactive SMB session. If client activity resumes, the session is automatically reestablished.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (always)
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the server policy is set to always sign packets.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (if client agrees)
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (if client agrees). This check verifies that the server policy is set to sign packets if the client agrees.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Microsoft network server: Disconnect clients when logon hours expire
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Users should not be permitted to remain logged on to the network after they have exceeded their permitted logon hours. In many cases, this indicates that a user forgot to log off before leaving for the day. However, it may also indicate that a user is attempting unauthorized access at a time when the system may be less closely monitored.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (AutoAdminLogon) Enable Automatic Logon Disabled
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: If enabled, this setting will allow a user to directly log on to the system with administrator privileges when the machine is rebooted. This would give full access to any unauthorized individual who reboots the computer. By default this setting is not enabled. If this setting exists, it should be disabled. If this capability exists, the default password will also be present in the registry, and must be removed.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (DisableIPSourceRouting) IP source routing protection level
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting protects against packet spoofing. Set to 2 to completely disable source routing.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (EnableDeadGWDetect) Allow automatic detection of dead network gateways
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: If this setting is enabled, it could lead to a denial of service.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (EnableICMPRedirect) Allow ICMP redirects to override OSPF generated routes
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check determines whether ICMP redirects are allowed to override OSPF generated routes.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (KeepAliveTime) How often keep-alive packets are sent in milliseconds
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the system is configured to control how often TCP attempts to verify that an idle connection is still intact by sending a keep-alive packet.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (NoDefaultExempt) Enable NoDefaultExempt for IPSec Filtering (recommended)
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: MSS: (NoDefaultExempt) Enable NoDefaultExempt for IPSec Filtering

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (NoDriveTypeAutoRun) Disable Autorun for all drives
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the system is configured to turn off the Autorun feature on all drives

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (NoNameReleaseOnDemand) Allow the computer to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the system is configured to prevent release of its NetBIOS name when a name-release request is received.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (NtfsDisable8dot3NameCreation) Enable the computer to stop generating 8.3 style filenames
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check determines whether the system is allowed to generate 8.3 style filenames.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (PerformRouterDiscovery) Allow IRDP to detect and configure DefaultGateway addresses
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the system is configured to disable the Internet Router Discovery Protocol (IDRP), which could lead to a denial of service.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (SafeDllSearchMode) Enable Safe DLL search mode
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The default search behavior, when an application calls a function in a Dynamic Link Library (DLL), is to search the current directory followed by the directories contained in the systems path environment variable. An unauthorized DLL inserted into an applications working directory could allow malicious code to be run on the system. Creating the SafeDllSearchMode registry key and setting the appropriate value forces the system to search the %Systemroot% for the DLL before searching the current directory or the rest of the path.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (ScreenSaverGracePeriod) The time in seconds before the screen saver grace period expires
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the system is configured to have password protection take effect immediately when the screen saver becomes active.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (SynAttackProtect) Syn attack protection level
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the system is configured to protect against Syn attacks. The setting should be set to "Connections time out sooner if a SYN attack is detected."

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (TCPMaxConnectResponseRetransmissions) SYN-ACK retransmissions when a connection request is not acknowledged
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the system is configured to control the maximum number of times that TCP retransmits a SYN before aborting the attempt.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (TCPMaxDataRetransmissions) How many times unacknowledged data is retransmitted
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the system is configured to control the maximum number of times that TCP retransmits unacknowledged data segments before aborting the attempt.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: MSS: (WarningLevel) percentage threshold for the security event log at which the system will generate a warning
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the system is configured to generate a warning when the Security Event Log has reached a defined threshold. If the system is configured to write to an audit server, or is configured to automatically archive full logs, then this check does not apply.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network access: Allow anonymous SID-Name translation
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Determines if an anonymous user can request security identifier (SID) attributes for another user or use a SID to get the corresponding username.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: If this setting is disabled, it allows anonymous logon users (null session connections) to list all account names, thus providing a map of potential points to attack the system.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts and shares
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: If this setting is disabled, it allows anonymous logon users (null session connections) to list all account names and enumerate all shared resources, thus providing a map of potential points to attack the system.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network access: Do not allow storage of credentials or .NET Passports for network authentication
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting controls the storage of authentication credentials or .NET passports on the local system. Such credentials should never be stored on the local machine as that may lead to account compromise.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network access: Let Everyone permissions apply to anonymous users
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting helps define the permissions that anonymous users have. If this setting is enabled then anonymous users have the same rights and permissions as the built-in Everyone group. Anonymous users should not have these permissions or rights.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network access: Named Pipes that can be accessed anonymously
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Network access: Named Pipes that can be accessed anonymously. Pipes are internal system communications processes. They are identified internally by ID numbers that vary between systems. To make access to these processes easier, these pipes are given names that do not vary between systems. This setting controls which of these pipes anonymous users may access.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network access: Remotely accessible registry paths
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Network access: Remotely accessible registry paths. This setting controls which registry paths are accessible from a remote computer.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network access: Shares that can be accessed anonymously
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting controls which network shares may be accessed by an anonymous user. The default setting includes the shares, DFS$, and COMCFG. It is recommended that they be left as the default setting.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network access: Sharing and security model for local accounts
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Windows XP includes two network-sharing security models Classic and Guest only. It is recommended that the Classic mode be used.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network security: Do not store LAN Manager hash value on next password change
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting controls whether or not a LAN Manager hash of the password is stored in the SAM the next time the password is changed. The LAN Manager hash is a weak encryption algorithm and there are several tools available that use this hash to retrieve account passwords.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network security: Force logoff when logon hours expire
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting controls whether or not users are forced to log off when their allowed logon hours expire. If logon hours are set for users, then this should be enforced.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network security: LAN Manager authentication level
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The Kerberos v5 authentication protocol is the default for authentication of users who are logging on to domain accounts from computers that are running Windows. The Kerberos protocol is the protocol of choice in Windows systems, when there is a choice. The Windows NTLM protocol was the default for authentication in Microsoft Windows NT version 4.0. It is retained in Windows 2000 for compatibility with clients and servers that are running Windows NT version 4.0 and earlier. It is also used to authenticate logons to stand-alone computers that are running Windows 2000.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network security: LDAP client signing requirements
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting controls the signing requirements for LDAP clients. This setting should be set to Negotiate signing or Require signing depending on the environment and type of LDAP server in use.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network security: Minimum session security for NTLM SSP based (including secure RPC) clients
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Starting with Windows 2000 Microsoft has implemented a variety of security support providers for use with RPC sessions. In a homogenous Windows XP environment, all of the options should be enabled and testing should be performed in a heterogeneous environment to determine the maximum-security level that provides reliable functionality.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Network security: Minimum session security for NTLM SSP based (including secure RPC) servers
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Starting with Windows 2000 Microsoft has implemented a variety of security support providers for use with RPC sessions. In a homogenous Windows XP environment, all of the options should be enabled and testing should be performed in a heterogeneous environment to determine the maximum-security level that provides reliable functionality.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Recovery console: Allow automatic administrative logon
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: If this option is enabled, the Recovery Console does not require you to provide a password and will automatically log on to the system, giving Administrator access to system files. By default, the Recovery Console requires you to provide the password for the Administrator account before accessing the system.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Recovery console: Allow floppy copy and access to all drives and all folders
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Enabling this option enables the Recovery Console SET command, which allows you to set Recovery Console environment variables. This permits floppy copy and access to all drives and folders. It should be disabled.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Shutdown: Allow system to be shut down without having to log on
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Displaying the shutdown button may allow individuals to shut down a system anonymously. Only authenticated users should be allowed to shut down the system. Preventing display of this button in the logon dialog box, ensures that individuals who shut down the system are authorized and tracked in the systems Security event log.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Shutdown: Clear virtual memory pagefile
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Virtual memory support of Windows XP uses a system page file to swap blocks of memory not actively being used to disk. While Windows XP is running, this file is opened exclusively by the operating system, thus ensuring it is reasonably protected. However, the system page file should be wiped clean of all user data when the system shuts down. This ensures that sensitive information that may be in the page file is not available for retrieval by an anonymous user.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: System cryptography: Use FIPS compliant algorithms for encryption, hashing, and signing
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting ensures that the system uses algorithms that are FIPS compliant for encryption, hashing, and signing. FIPS compliant algorithms meet specific standards established by the U.S. Government and should be the algorithms used for all OS encryption functions.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: System objects: Default owner for objects created by members of the Administrators group
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Either the object creator or the Administrators group owns objects created by members of the Administrators group. In order to ensure accurate auditing and proper accountability, the default owner should be the object creator.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting controls the behavior of non-Windows subsystems when dealing with the case of arguments or commands. Case sensitivity could lead to the access of files or commands that should be restricted. To prevent this from happening, case insensitivity should be required.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: System objects: Strengthen default permissions of internal system objects (e.g. Symbolic Links)
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: System objects: Strengthen default permissions of internal system objects (e.g. Symbolic Links). Windows systems maintains an internal list of shared system resources such as DOS device names, mutexes, and semaphores. Each type of object is created with a default DACL that specifies who can access the objects with what permissions. If this policy is enabled, the default DACL is stronger, allowing non-admin users to read shared objects, but not modify shared objects that they did not create.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: User Rights Assignment Settings
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description:
The NIST security templates specify which groups (e.g., Administrators, Users) have certain user rights. The goal is for each group to have only the necessary rights, and for users to only belong to the necessary groups. This is the principle of least privilege, described previously in Section 2.2. Examples of user rights that can be specified are as follows:
Accessing the system remotely and locally
Performing backups
Changing the time and date on the system
Managing the logs
Shutting down the system.Verify that the user right '' has been granted appropriately.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Right To Access This Computer From The Network
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Verify that the user right 'Access This Computer From The Network' has been granted appropriately. NOTE: This can break IPSec see Microsoft Knowledge Base article 823659 for further guidance

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\User Rights Assignment

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Verify that the user right 'Act As Part Of The Operating System' has been granted appropriately.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Verify that the user right 'Change the System Time' has been granted appropriately.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Right To Create A Pagefile
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Verify that the user right 'Create A Pagefile' has been granted appropriately.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Right To Create A Token Object
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Verify that the user right 'Create A Token Object' has been granted appropriately.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Right To Create Global Objects
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Verify that the user right 'Create Global Objects' has been granted appropriately.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Right To Create Permanent Shared Objects
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Verify that the user right 'Create Permanent Shared Objects' has been granted appropriately.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Administrators Have Right To Debug Programs
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Verify that the user right 'Debug Programs' has been granted appropriately.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\User Rights Assignment

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Denied Access To This Computer From The Network
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Verify that the user right 'Deny Access To This Computer From The Network' has been granted appropriately.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Verify that the user right 'Force Shutdown From A Remote System' has been granted appropriately.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Right To Increase Scheduling Priority
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Verify that the user right 'Increase Scheduling Priority' has been granted appropriately.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: System Services Group
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: This section identifies requirements for the state of certain services on the system.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: System Services Settings
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: This section identifies requirements for the state of certain services on the system.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Alerter Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Sends administrative alerts to the console.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Background Intelligent Transfer Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Transfers files in the background using idle network bandwidth. If the service is disabled, then any applications that depend on BITS, such as Windows Update or MSN Explorer, will be unable to automatically download programs and other information. Impact: Windows Update

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: ClipBook Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The ClipBook service enables the ClipBook Viewer to create and share pages of data for review by remote users.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Computer Browser Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Computer Browser service maintains an up-to-date list of computers on your network and supplies the list to programs that request it.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Error Reporting Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Error Reporting Service collects, stores, and reports unexpected application errors or closures to Microsoft. It also authorizes error reporting for services and applications that run in non-standard environments.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Fast User Switching Compatibility Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Fast User Switching Compatibility service provides management for applications that require assistance in a multiple user environment.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Fax Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Fax Service, a Telephony Application Programming Interface (TAPI)-compliant service, provides fax capabilities from users' computers.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: FTP Publishing Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The FTP Publishing Service provides FTP connectivity and administration through the Microsoft Internet Information Server (IIS) snap-in.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Indexing Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Indexing Service indexes the contents and properties of files on local and remote computers and provides rapid access to files through a flexible querying language.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Messenger Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Messenger service sends messages to or receives messages from users, computers, administrators, and the Alerter service.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: NetMeeting Remote Desktop Sharing Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This service allows authorized users to remotely access your Windows desktop with the Microsoft NetMeeting(r) application from another personal computer over an intranet.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network DDE Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Network DDE service provides network transport and security for Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE) for programs that run on the same computer or on different computers.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network DDE dsdm Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Network DDE DSDM service manages DDE network shares.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Routing And Remote Access Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Routing and Remote Access service provides multi-protocol LAN-to-LAN, LAN-to-WAN, VPN, and NAT routing services. This service also provides dial-up and VPN remote access services

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: SSDP Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Universal Plug and Play host service that is included with Windows XP supports peer-to-peer Plug and Play functionality for network devices.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Telnet Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Telnet service for Windows provides ASCII terminal sessions to Telnet clients. It supports two types of authentication and supports four types of terminals: American National Standards Institute (ANSI), VT-100, VT-52, and VTNT.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Terminal Services Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Unnecessary services should not be running on the system. Services typically run under the local System Account, which generally have more permissions than are required by the service. Compromising a service could allow an intruder to obtain System permissions and open the system to a variety of attacks.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Universal Plug And Play Device Host Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Universal Plug and Play Device Host service supports peer-to-peer Universal Plug and Play (UPnP) functionality for network devices.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: WebClient Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The WebClient service allows Win32 applications to access documents on the Internet.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Wireless Zero Configuration
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This service enables automatic configuration for IEEE 802.11 wireless adapters for wireless communications.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: WMI Performance Adapter
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The WMI Performance Adapter service provides performance library information from WMI High Performance providers.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: WWW Publishing Services Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The World Wide Web Publishing Service provides Web connectivity and administration of Web sites through the MMC IIS snap-in.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Alerter Service Disabled
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Unnecessary services should not be running on the system. Services typically run under the local System Account, which generally have more permissions than are required by the service. Compromising a service could allow an intruder to obtain System permissions and open the system to a variety of attacks.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Network Connection Settings
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description:
The features for implementing and administering small networks are described as follows:
-- Internet Connection Sharing (ICS) --
ICS provides Internet access for a home or small office network by using one common connection as the Internet gateway. The ICS host is the only computer that is directly connected to the Internet. Multiple ICS clients simultaneously use the common Internet connection and benefit from Internet services as if the clients were directly connected to the Internet service provider (ISP). Security is enhanced when ICS is enabled because only the ICS host computer is visible to the Internet. The addresses of ICS clients are hidden from the Internet rendering ICS clients invisible to the Internet. In addition, ICS simplifies the configuration of small networks by providing local private network services, such as name resolution and addressing.
Note: You should not use Internet Connection Sharing in an existing network with Windows 2000 Server domain controllers, Domain Name System (DNS) servers, gateways, Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) servers, or systems configured for static IP addresses.
-- Internet Connection Firewall (ICF) --
With ICF, the firewall checks all communications that cross the connection between your network and the Internet and is selective about which responses from the Internet it allows. ICF protects only the computer on which it is enabled. If ICF is enabled on the Internet Connection Sharing (ICS) host computer, however, ICS clients that use the shared Internet connection for Internet connectivity are protected because they cannot be seen from outside your network. For this reason, you should always enable ICF on the ICS host computer. In addition, if there are clients on your network with direct Internet connections, or if you have a stand-alone computer that is connected to the Internet, then you should enable ICF on those Internet connections as well.
-- Network Bridge --
Network Bridge removes the need for routing and bridging hardware in a home or small office network that consists of multiple LAN segments. With Network Bridge, multiple LAN segments become a single IP subnet, even if the LAN segments are of mixed network media types. Network Bridge automates the configuration and management of the address allocation, routing, and name resolution that is typically required in a network that consists of multiple LAN segments.
Caution If neither ICF nor ICS is enabled on your network, do not set up Network Bridge between the public Internet connection and the private network connection. Setting up Network Bridge between the public Internet connection and the private network connection creates an unprotected link between your network and the Internet, leaving your network vulnerable to external attacks. When either ICF or ICS is enabled, this risk is mitigated.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Security Patches
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Securing a given computer has become increasingly important. As such, it is essential to keep a host up to current patch levels to eliminate known vulnerabilities and weaknesses. In conjunction with antivirus software and a personal firewall, patching goes a long way to securing a host against outside attacks and exploitation. Microsoft provides two mechanisms for distributing security updates: Automatic Updates and Microsoft Update. In smaller environments, either method may be sufficient for keeping systems current with patches. Other environments typically have a software change management control process or a patch management program that tests patches before deploying them; distribution may then occur through local Windows Update Services (WUS) or Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) servers, which provide approved security patches for use by the Automatic Updates feature.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Security Patches Up-To-Date
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Keep systems up to current patch levels to eliminate known vulnerabilities and weaknesses.

boolean_question.question_text: Does the Windows setting "Enable screen saver" located at "User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Control Panel\Personalization" have the value Enabled?
Does the Windows setting "Password protect the screen saver" located at "User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Control Panel\Personalization" have the value Enabled?
Does the Windows setting "Screen Saver timeout" located at "User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Control Panel\Personalization" have the value Enabled:900 seconds?
Does the Windows setting "Do not preserve zone information in file attachments" located at "User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Attachment Manager" have the value Disabled?
Does the Windows setting "Hide mechanisms to remove zone information" located at "User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Attachment Manager" have the value Enabled?
Does the Windows setting "Notify antivirus programs when opening attachments" located at "User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Attachment Manager" have the value Enabled?

metadata.title: Do Not Show First Use Dialog Boxes
metadata.description: Do Not Show First Use Dialog Boxes This policy prevents the Privacy Options and Installation Options dialog boxes from being displayed the first time a user starts Windows Media Player. This policy prevents the dialog boxes which allow users to select privacy, file types, and other desktop options from being displayed when the Player is first started. Some of the options can be configured by using other Windows Media Player group policies. When this policy is not configured or disabled, the dialog boxes are displayed when the user starts the Player for the first time.

metadata.title: Prevent Automatic Updates
metadata.description: Prevents users from being prompted to update Windows Media Player. This policy prevents the Player from being updated and prevents users with administrator rights from being prompted to update the Player if an updated version is available. The Check for Player Updates command on the Help menu in the Player is not available. In addition, none of the time intervals in the Check for updates section on the Player tab are selected or available. When this policy is not configured or disabled, Check for Player Updates is available only to users with administrator rights and they may be prompted to update the Player if an updated version is available. By default, users with administrator rights can select how frequently updates are checked for. Users without administrator rights do not see Check for Player Updates and are never prompted to update the Player even without this policy.

Audits the successful attempts to access directory services.
Audits failed attempts to access directory services.
Audits the successful and failed attempts to access directory services.

external_variable.comment: Audit logon events

possible_value.hint: Does not audit attempts of users logging on, logging off, or making a network connection to the local computer.
Audits the successful attempts of users logging on, logging off, or making a network connection to the local computer.
Audits failed attempts of users logging on, logging off, or making a network connection to the local computer.
Audits the successful and failed attempts of users logging on, logging off, or making a network connection to the local computer.

external_variable.comment: Audit object access

possible_value.hint: Does not audit attempts of a user accessing an object that has its own SACL specified.
Audits the successful attempts of a user accessing an object that has its own SACL specified.
Audits failed attempts of a user accessing an object that has its own SACL specified.
Audits the successful and failed attempts of a user accessing an object that has its own SACL specified.

external_variable.comment: Audit policy change

possible_value.hint: Does not audit attempt to change user rights assignment policies, audit policies, and trust policies.
Audits the successful attempt to change user rights assignment policies, audit policies, and trust policies.
Audits failed attempt to change user rights assignment policies, audit policies, and trust policies.
Audits the successful and failed attempt to change user rights assignment policies, audit policies, and trust policies.

external_variable.comment: Audit privilege use

possible_value.hint: Does not audit attempts by a user in exercising a user right.
Audits the successful attempts by a user in exercising a user right.
Audits failed attempts by a user in exercising a user right.
Audits the successful and failed attempts by a user in exercising a user right.

external_variable.comment: Audit system events

possible_value.hint: Does not audit attempts of a user restarting or shutting down the computer or when an event occurs that affects either the system security or the security log.
Audits the successful attempts of a user restarting or shutting down the computer or when an event occurs that affects either the system security or the security log.
Audits failed attempts of a user restarting or shutting down the computer or when an event occurs that affects either the system security or the security log.
Audits the successful and failed attempts of a user restarting or shutting down the computer or when an event occurs that affects either the system security or the security log.
